content: The Act may be cited as the "Colonel Charles Young Congressional Gold Medal Act". Colonel Charles Young was a distinguished African-American officer in the United States Army, the third African-American to graduate from West Point, and a commander in the Spanish-American War and the Mexican Punitive Expedition. He was also the first Black military attache to a foreign government and the highest ranking Black Officer in the US Armed Forces at the start of World War I. Born into slavery in 1864 in Kentucky. Colonel Charles Young, born into slavery in 1864 in Kentucky, was a distinguished African-American officer in the United States Army. He was the third African-American to graduate from West Point and served in various military roles, including leading the military sciences department at Wilberforce College and being the first African-American Superintendent of a National Park. Colonel Charles Young served in various military roles, including as a military attache in Haiti, the Philippines, and Liberia, where he supervised infrastructure construction. Colonel Charles Young demonstrated exceptional leadership during the 1916 Punitive Expedition in Mexico, leading a successful cavalry charge against Pancho Villa's forces without losing a single man. As a result, he was promoted to Lieutenant Colonel and became the first African-American to achieve the rank of colonel. Colonel Charles Young was the first African-American to achieve the rank of colonel in the United States Army. Colonel Charles Young was the first African-American to achieve the rank of colonel in the United States Army. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. Colonel Charles Young, the first African-American colonel in the US Army, will be honored with a gold medal by Congress. The medal will be designed by the Secretary of the Treasury and presented to the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center. The National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center in Wilberforce, Ohio will receive a gold medal honoring Colonel Charles Young. Congress recommends that the museum display or loan the medal for viewing at other locations associated with Colonel Young's life. The Secretary is authorized to produce and sell bronze duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. Medals created under this Act are considered national medals according to US law.
